Award.AwardTitle: Polarization of Plant Cell Division by Receptor-Like Proteins
Award.AbstractNarration:
Polarized (asymmetric) cell divisions produce cells with different properties and fates, as well as generate cellular diversity during the development of plants and other eukaryotes. However, very little is known about molecular mechanisms underlying polarized cell division in plants. We previously discovered a pair of receptor-like proteins, PAN1 and PAN2, that work together to polarize the asymmetric divisions producing subsidiary cells of stomatal complexes in the maize leaf epidermis, which regulate the exchange of oxygen, carbon dioxide, and water between the leaf and surrounding air. In this project, we will build on our earlier findings using tools of genetics, microscopy, proteomics, and biochemistry to advance our understanding of how PAN receptors promote the polarization of subsidiary mother cell divisions. Specifically, we will determine where PAN2 protein acts in the cell, elucidate the connection between PANs and other known regulators of cell polarity, analyze the role of PANs in the spatial regulation of secretion and/or endocytosis, and identify other proteins that PANs interact with to promote division polarity.

Data generated by this project will be made available to the public through publications and publicly accessible websites, accessible via http://www.biology.ucsd.edu/labs/smith/; biological materials will be maintained by the principal investigator and distributed upon request. In addition to elucidating processes of fundamental importance for plant development, this project will also positively impact science education. A postdoctoral fellow, two graduate students, and multiple undergraduates will receive interdisplinary training through participation in this project. In addition, a week-long plant genomics laboratory module addressing California Life Sciences Standards for 7th grade will be implemented each year of the project period in two central San Diego public middle schools: Grant and Roosevelt. Participation in the module will benefit about 350 7th graders per year at these two schools, most of whom are underrepresented minority students at Roosevelt, where the minority enrollment is 80%.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Multicellular tissues and organs are composed of distinct cell types arranged in patterns that facilitate their functions. The correct specification and placement of these cells is often achieved via asymmetric division, which produce daughter cells having divergent developmental fates. Prior to dividing asymmetrically, cells must polarize. This grant aimed to understand the mechanisms of cell polarization in plants prior to asymmetric division. This was done using the plant genetic model maize (corn) by studying an asymmetric division that produces a specialized cell type within plant stomata: subsidiary cells. We identified and characterized proteins required for the polarization of subsidiary mother cells (SMCs). We studied the molecular mechanisms of SMC polarization prior to asymmetric division, producing stomata that are essential for leaf function as a photosynthetic tissue. Specifically, we focused on two receptor-like proteins, PAN1 and PAN2, and the molecular pathway in which they function to promote SMC polarization.

 

Intellectual Merit

Major Research Findings:

Localization and function of PAN1 and PAN2. The PAN1 and PAN2 receptor proteins both promote SMC polarization. Previously, we had determined that PAN1 protein itself has a polarized distribution in SMCs. During this project we discovered that PAN2 has a similarly polarized distribution, which is achieved before PAN1 polarization, In addition, we discovered that PAN1 and PAN2 proteins have additional functions and subcellular localizations the other does not share. Thus, these proteins participate in distinct processes in addition to working together to achieve SMC polarization.

The role of actin-nucleating proteins in subsidiary cell polarization. We previously identified BRK1 as a protein that regulates the assembly of actin filaments. Mutants lacking this protein, like pan1 and pan2 mutants, have aberrantly shaped subsidiary cells due to a failure in SMC polarization. We identified another protein, BRK3, as a partner for BRK1 in the regulation of actin filament assembly. We showed that the polarization of BRK1 protein in SMCs occurs very soon after birth of these cells, before polarized accumulation of PAN1 and PAN2. We further showed that BRK1 and BRK3 are required for polarization of PAN1 and PAN2, revealing a role for actin in PAN polarization. Thus, we delineated multiple steps in the molecular mechanism of SMC polarization.

Identification of novel proteins contributing to subsidiary cell polarization. While several steps in SMC polarization have been defined in molecular terms, it is clear that we are still missing key players in the maize SMC polarization pathway. We initiated two complementary approaches to finding additional proteins that function in a common pathway with PAN proteins to promote SMC polarization. Firstly, we used proteomic methods to identify proteins that physically interact with PAN1 and/or PAN2, or whose accumulation or state of activation depends on PAN proteins. Secondly, we initiated a genetic screen to identify mutations that enhance the pan2 mutant phenotype. Thus, using these approaches, we have identified several candidates for new components of the PAN-dependent SMC polarization pathway.

Impact: Developing our understanding of the PAN pathway is providing unique insights into the control of division polarity in plants, where conserved regulators of division asymmetry identified in other eukaryotes are absent. Our work also shows the power of a systems approach integrating multiple strategies to identify new components of a pathway.

 

Broader Impacts

                  Several activities connected to this grant contributed preparing the next generation(s) of scientists and increasing public understanding of science. The most significant of these was a week-long plant genomics lab module for 7th graders designed and supported (and in some classes, taught) by the PI, which ran in dozens of central San Diego public middle school classrooms throughout the life of the project. Altogether, approximately 1200 students participated in the module, mostly at Roosevelt Middle School where underrepresented minority enrollment is 80%. Participation in the module offered 7th graders a research-like experience involving contemporary genome analysis methods while deepening their grasp of 7th grade California Life Sciences Standards and opening students’ eyes to possibilities for careers in science.  The PI and postdoc supported by this grant also participated in a variety of science outreach activities that increase public understanding of science such as the San Diego Science Festival and middle and high school science fairs.

 Participation in this project also prepared several young scientists for future science-related careers. On the strength of the training, mentoring and accomplishments in this project, one postdoc supported by this grant attained a faculty position at the University of New Mexico and the other continues his work as a scientist at the University of Florida. Two masters students and eight undergraduates (including one Hispanic male) students received science training through participation in this project and are using it in a variety of ways, as they continue with their studies or as members of the science workforce.
